content: hello i'm martin iguagu of nedufitness.com i'm here in austin texas at fitness 360. so how do you get back into shape after not exercising for a long time now i'm assuming this may be you if it's not you could tell somebody who you know this may be for but it's a topic that's discussed by many people what do we do well first things first you have to decide to start now write it down make it a goal whatever it is we don't want to be outlandish here right so one of the first things you should do in writing your goal on deciding to get back into shape is start off by walking park further from the grocery grocery store just make sure that you're doing something every single day because as i was taught inch by inch is a cinch and yard by yard it's hard so doing the little things first always count so one thing you can do is set up to do two sets of 10 to 15 reps of an exercise now you ask what type of exercises do i get started on i know well one great exercise to do is push-ups push-ups are simple they use body weight you can do it anywhere and you don't have to be at a gym to do it you can do it right now and that's the most important thing so just going on the ground and doing push-ups for like 10 to 15 reps every single day also you could do body weight squats body weight squats are great for developing your lower body strength at the same time you're using your body weight see you can't get hurt but you decided to start now now when walking into a gym you ask yourself what are some exercises i can do in the gym just to get started if you haven't been working out in a long time one thing you can do is total body exercises or as i like to call it compound movements so squats with the bar bell on your back are great because it helps to develop core strength and stability at the same time lower body strength another great exercise to do is the flat bench press and this is also a compound exercise this is used primarily to develop a lot of the upper body muscles pectoralis major especially also your shoulder muscles and your tricep muscles so at least you decide to start so now you need to find someone to hold you accountable whenever you go out to these places because a lot of times it's easy to say i'm going to do this but who's going to tell you you're going to do it right you wake up in the morning at 6 00 a.m and you realize i don't want to wake up because i don't have to do it we got to find accountability people this is the time now this is your goals that you have set for you start off today just walking around the neighborhood do something like remember start off with machines machines are great you don't have to worry about hitting it too hard what's important is you have a win every single day so you set small goals and you accomplish those things over time then we add another goal right now you want to focus on wellness rather than weight loss and we'll go from there i have no doubt you'll reach your goal if you just start now and that's how you get back into shape after no exercise for a long time you
title: How to Get Back Into Shape After No Exercise for a Long Time : Full Fitness Training
author: eHowFitness

key_facts: Martin Iguagu is the founder of nedufitness.com.
The video was recorded in Austin, Texas at Fitness 360.
The topic addresses returning to fitness after a long period of inactivity.
Starting with small daily actions is recommended for re-establishing fitness habits.
Walking further from the grocery store is suggested as an initial physical activity.
Push-ups are bodyweight exercises that can be done anywhere without equipment.
Bodyweight squats help develop lower body strength and stability.
Compound movements like barbell back squats improve core strength and lower body development.
Flat bench press is a compound exercise targeting pectoralis major, shoulders, and triceps.
Accountability partners are essential for maintaining consistency in workouts.
Machines in gyms are recommended for beginners due to their safety and ease of use.
Focusing on wellness rather than weight loss is advised during the initial phase.
Consistency through daily small wins builds long-term fitness success.
The principle 'inch by inch is a cinch, yard by yard it's hard' applies to gradual progress.
Writing down goals increases commitment and clarity about intentions.
Daily practice of 10–15 push-up reps is a feasible starting point.
Two sets of 10–15 reps are recommended for beginner exercise routines.
Bodyweight exercises minimize injury risk when starting out.
Beginners should prioritize form and consistency over intensity.
Motivation often fades without external accountability.
Morning workouts are harder to maintain without a support system.
Progressive goal-setting helps sustain motivation over time.
Fitness recovery begins with immediate action, not waiting for perfect conditions.
Wellness includes physical, mental, and behavioral health aspects beyond just weight.
key_opinions: Starting with walking further from the grocery store is a practical first step.
Push-ups are one of the best exercises for beginners due to accessibility.
Bodyweight squats are effective for building foundational lower body strength.
Compound movements should be prioritized for efficient muscle development.
The flat bench press is ideal for developing upper body strength effectively.
Accountability is crucial for overcoming procrastination and lack of motivation.
Machines are safer and more approachable for people returning to exercise.
Focusing on wellness leads to sustainable results compared to short-term weight loss goals.
Small daily wins create momentum and reinforce positive behavior patterns.
Success in fitness depends more on consistency than on extreme effort initially.
It’s better to start simple and gradually increase intensity than to overdo it early.
People who decide to start now have a high chance of reaching their goals.
The mindset shift from 'I’ll do it someday' to 'I’ll do it today' is critical.
Exercise should be enjoyable and integrated into daily life, not seen as punishment.
A gym environment can be intimidating; starting with machines reduces anxiety.
Self-determination is key, but external support accelerates progress.
Avoiding overly ambitious goals prevents burnout and discouragement.
Long-term fitness success comes from habit formation, not quick fixes.
Mindset matters more than equipment or location when restarting fitness.
The journey should begin with self-compassion and patience.
key_datapoints: Start with 10 to 15 reps of push-ups per day.
Perform two sets of 10 to 15 reps for each exercise.
Focus on daily activity, even if minimal.
No specific duration mentioned for walking, but daily consistency is emphasized.
Barbell back squats are highlighted as a compound movement.
Flat bench press targets pectoralis major, shoulders, and triceps.
No exact timeline provided for achieving fitness goals.
Accountability is described as essential but no metric given.
No percentage or statistical data on success rates or dropout rates.
No mention of calorie expenditure, heart rate zones, or workout frequency schedules.
No specific number of weeks or months for progression to next stage.
No data on injury rates or recovery times for beginners.
No reference to body composition changes or measurable outcomes.
No mention of cost, time investment, or equipment prices.
No data on user demographics or audience size.
No performance benchmarks or progression milestones defined.
No mention of rest periods between sets.
No indication of how many days per week to exercise.
No reference to hydration, nutrition, or sleep impact on fitness.
No statistics on adherence rates or retention in fitness programs.
